item.title: Personal thoughts \#1
item.description: I find myself putting this thought in writing on a night seemingly like many others. What prompted me to talk about this is a chapter in “The Four Loves” by C.S.Lewis called Friendship. With this return to less restrictive measures I am discovering again what is the root of a friendship, what truly makes me say: “These are my friends.” From a biological point of view, friendship is the least natural of affections.

item.title: Invisible influence
item.description: What causes us to make decisions in life? We think the answer is obvious. People know what’s good for them. They weigh their options and make a rational decision! When a waiter in a diner asks if you’d like to order dessert after a meal the answer is easy. My belly isn’t full + I love sweets = of course I’d like dessert! In other words, YOU make YOUR OWN decisions.

item.title: One small step for an ape, one big step for humankind
item.description: Can you play video games using your brain as a controller? The answer is yes Neuralink, a company founded by Elon Musk in 2016, has recently been all over the news as it has managed to do something extremely fascinating. In fact, they managed to get a monkey to play a video game, albeit a simple one compared to more modern video games. Well but it doesn’t end there.

item.title: How to create a site using HUGO
item.description: Want to have a site similar to mine without spending a dime? Do you want it a little more beautiful? Then you’re in the right place! A few days ago I had a few hours free during an afternoon and I wanted to try my hand at what I thought was one of the greatest feats in human history. Well, thank goodness, it wasn’t as hard as I thought it would be.

item.title: Books
item.description: Libri in lettura I quattro amori (C.S. Lewis) L’origine delle specie (Charles Darwin) Libri da leggere Bioetica (Adriano Pessina) Bunker Diary (kevin Brooks) Data and Goliath (Bruce Schneier) Dottor Jakyill and mr Hyde Entropia e Arte Evoluzione e libertà (Hans Jonas) How Not To Be Wrong (Jordan Ellenberg) I duellanti (Conrad) I problemi della filosofia (Bertrand Russel) Il Gene (Siddartha Mukherjee) Il morbo dei dottori. la strana storia di Ignac semmelweis L’abbraccio (Mikel Azurmendi) L’ordine del tempo (Carlo Rovelli) L’origine della specie (Charles Darwin) Le farò un po' male (Adam Kay) Liftoff (Eric Berger) Life at the Speed of Light: The Doble Helix and the Dawn of Digital Life Molto forte, incredibilmente vicino (Foer) Non ti ho mai promesso un giardino di rose (Greenberg Joanne) Open (Andre Agassi) Regenesis: How Synthetic Biology will Reinvent Nature and Ourselves Se una notte di inverno un viaggiatore (Italo Calvino) Sulla traccia di Nives (Erri de Luca) The Hero Code: Lessons Learned from Lives Well Lived (Admiral William H.

item.title: My first Post
item.description: Hi everyone! I am writing this page not knowing what will become of this project. I’m sure something will come to me though. What made me start this blog even though I didn’t really know what would become of it is the book: Start Now, Get Perfect Later by Rob Moore. I listened to the summary of it on 4books, a startup by Marco Montemagno, and it convinced me. The fundamental message is the one expressed in the title.
